elements.content: Solid-state synthesis (S3) is an attractive approach to organic synthesis as in principle it offers minimal solvent waste and high yield. However, many functional groups are ill-suited for S3 reactions, which tend to only proceed when substrates are aligned in the solid-state according to the topochemical principle. The aim of this work is to use high yield, low-waste synthetic methods to develop a library of novel Schiff bases that can be utilized as linker ligands to prepare coordination networks. Herein, we report that eight pyridyl- and/or imidazolyl-substituted Schiff bases, 1–8, five of which are new chemical entities, can be prepared via reaction of an amine and an aldehyde without the use of solvent. All eight compounds were prepared via solvent-drop grinding (SDG) in multigram scale in >95% yield and each was characterized by FTIR, 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopies and single crystal X-ray diffraction. One of the aldehydes used is a liquid under ambient conditions so its reactions to form 1–4 are not classified as S3 reactions whereas the other aldehydes are solids and 5–8 are therefore S3 reactions. The SDG solvents were selected in accordance with guidelines used by industry. 1–4 were also prepared quantitatively via addition of the liquid aldehyde (4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde) to a solution of the corresponding amine. That 1–8 contain functional groups suitable for coordinating with metal cations will enable 1–8 to serve as linker ligands in coordination networks as exemplified by 5, which forms a parallel interpenetrated coordination network with square lattice, sql, topology.

elements.content:
A library of Schiff base linker ligands has been synthesized in high yield with low-waste by solvent-drop grinding.

Introduction

The tenets of crystal engineering have enabled a priori design and development of 2D and 3D coordination networks such as Metal–Organic Materials (MOMs), Metal–Organic Frameworks (MOFs) and Porous Coordination Polymers (PCPs). The crystal engineering concept that enabled the rapid development of coordination networks in the 1990s was the exploitation of ditopic ligands to serve as “spacers” or “linkers” between metal ion or metal cluster nodes. The most common type of 2D coordination networks are those with square lattice (sql) topology, which comprise 45% of reported structures. With respect to 3D coordination networks, diamondoid (dia) and primitive cubic (pcu) nets are the most commonly observed network topologies. This is unsurprising as tetrahedral and octahedral coordination geometries are the most common geometries for transition metals and, when linked by linear ditopic ligands, they tend to afford dia or pcu nets, respectively. 4,4′-Bipyridine, bipy, is the prototypal ditopic linear linker and remains the most frequently used organic linker, constituting 3822 entries (vs 1752 entries for terephthalate) in the MOF subset of the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD, v. 5.39).

Introduction

The tenets of crystal engineering have enabled a priori design and development of 2D and 3D coordination networks such as Metal-Organic Materials (MOMs), Metal-Organic Frameworks (MOFs) and Porous Coordination Polymers (PCPs). The crystal engineering concept that enabled the rapid development of coordination networks in the 1990s was the exploitation of ditopic ligands to serve as "spacers" or "linkers" between metal ion or metal cluster nodes. This is unsurprising as tetrahedral and octahedral coordination geometries are the most common geometries for transition metals and, when linked by linear ditopic ligands, they tend to afford dia  or pcu nets, respectively. 4,4'-Bipyridine, bipy, is the prototypal ditopic linear linker and remains the most frequently used organic linker, constituting 3822 entries (vs 1752 entries for terephthalate) in the MOF subset of the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD, v. 5.39).

elements.content: Hybrid Ultramicroporous Materials (HUMs) represent an emerging subclass of coordination networks that are also based on linear bipy-type organic linker ligands. The prototype, SIFSIX-1-Zn, comprises bipy linkers, inorganic (hexafluorosilicate, SIFSIX) linker anions and octahedral Zn2+ cationic nodes. The modularity of SIFSIX-1-Zn enables facile linker ligand and/or metal substitution and can offer exquisite control over pore size, especially in the ultramicropore (<0.7 nm) range, and pore chemistry. Tight fitting pores and strong electrostatics have enabled HUMs to set new performance benchmarks for challenging trace separations such as CO2/N2, C2H2/C2H4, C2H2/CO2, Xe/Kr, C3H6/C3H8, C4H6/n-C4H8/iso-C4H8, H2O/CH4 and SO2/CO2. In this context, we have recently shown how HUMs with closely related organic linkers can exhibit significant differences in their structures and properties. Such linker ligands are also known to afford different network structures from the same molecular building blocks, i.e., supramolecular isomers. Hence, there is motivation to investigate how subtle changes in the structure of a library of related organic linker ligands can influence coordination network structure and properties.

elements.content: Facile synthesis of linker ligands is almost a prerequisite if they are ultimately to be used for industrial scale applications. Solid-state synthesis (S3) offers promise in this context owing to minimal or no solvent waste and high yields. Further, the current generation of organic linker ligands tends to be limited to those that are commercially available or those prepared via conventional solution-based syntheses, which generally requires homogeneous transition-metal catalyst(s) and cumbersome purification protocols. In this context, it is perhaps ironic that the earliest crystal engineering studies focused upon organic synthesis as exemplified by Schmidt’s work on [2+2] photodimerization. S3 has since enjoyed rapid growth and remains an active area of research in crystal engineering. However, a limitation of S3 is its lack of general applicability because crystal packing tends to be difficult to control across a range of related substrates. Crystal engineering can address some of these limitations. For example, molecular templates or coordination polymers can enable photodimerization reactions to occur across a range of substrates. We have demonstrated that Cocrystal-Controlled Solid-State Synthesis or C 3 S 3 can enable preparation of novel imide condensation products via cocrystal intermediates.

elements.content: In the broader context, there is increasing awareness of mechanochemistry, the coupling of mechanical and chemical phenomena, as a powerful synthetic technique. As defined by IUPAC, a mechanochemical reaction is a chemical reaction that is induced by the direct absorption of mechanical energy, and can be achieved by grinding in a mortar and pestle or in a ball mill. Some of the earliest scientific reports on mechanochemistry date back to 19th century, when Lea detailed the decomposition of silver and mercury halides. However, according to Takacs, the first documented mechanochemical reaction goes back to the fourth century BC; the grinding of cinnabar with vinegar in a copper vessel to afford elemental mercury. Over the past decade, mechanochemistry has been exploited for the scaled-up syntheses of organic molecules, cocrystals and MOMs, and also for continuous manufacturing using twin-screw extrusion. Among compounds amenable to S3 are imines, including Schiff bases. Several groups have shown the efficient and rapid synthesis of a wide range of Schiff bases in the solid-state. Imines are a widely studied and used class of organic compounds thanks to their ready accessibility via condensation of primary amines with aldehydes, generally in the presence of an acid. Functionalized Schiff bases have been used as ligands in coordination chemistry and employed to mimic the function of metal ion/anions/nuetral molecule carriers for recognition and transportation. They have also been studied to understand and reproduce the catalytic activity of metalloenzymes and proteins. In particular, imines that serve as planar macrocyclic and macroacyclic ligands are well studied. However, this versatile class of compound remain underexplored as organic linkers in coordination networks. Our motivation for exploring novel imine linker ligands results from several factors: (i) their facile synthesis by condensation of carbonyl and primary amine substrates including S3; (ii) the availability of substrates with other donor groups (O, S, P, etc.); (iii) the possibility of post-synthetic functionalization of the aliphatic and/or aromatic moieties of the linker ligands; (iv) the amenability of imines to reduction offers polyamines that are less sensitive to hydrolysis, flexible and the NH groups can be further functionalized. Here, we explore S3 with use of minimal-solvent for the synthesis of eight Schiff bases, 1–8, each of which is suitable to serve as ditopic organic linker ligand. We also demonstrate the utility of one of these linker ligands, 5, for the preparation of a parallel interpenetrated coordination network.

elements.content: Reagents and solvents were procured from Sigma-Aldrich, Fluorochem or TCI and used as received. S3 reactions were performed using a Retsch MM400 shaker mill in a 10 mL steel vessel with one or two 10 mm steel balls at 30 Hz for the specified time. 1H and 13C Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectra were recorded on a Jeol EX270 or ECX400. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were measured on Empyrean diffractometer (PANalytical, Philips) using CuKα source. Thermogravimetric Analyses (TGA) were performed on a TA Instrument Q50 TG. Differential Scanning Calorimetry (DSC) analyses were carried out on a TA Instrument DSC Q20. Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) spectra were collected on a PerkinElmer Spectrum 100 spectrometer with Universal ATR accessory.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Aspects

Reagents and solvents were procured from Sigma-Aldrich, Fluorochem or TCI and used as received. S3 reactions were performed using a Retsch MM400 shaker mill in a 10 mL steel vessel with one or two 10 mm steel balls at 30 Hz for the specified time. 1H and 13C Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectra were recorded on a Jeol EX270 or ECX400. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were measured on Empyrean diffractometer (PANalytical, Philips) using CuKα source. Thermogravimetric Analyses (TGA) were performed on a TA Instrument Q50 TG. Differential Scanning Calorimetry (DSC) analyses were carried out on a TA Instrument DSC Q20. Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) spectra were collected on a PerkinElmer Spectrum 100 spectrometer with Universal ATR accessory.

elements.content: Crystal structures of all synthesized compounds were determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD). with either Mo Kα (λ = 0.710 73 Å) or Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) radiation and Bruker D8 Quest fixed-chi diffractometer equipped with Photon II or Photon 100 detector, and the nitrogen-flow Oxford Cryosystem attachment. Unit-cell determination, data reduction and absorption correction (multiscan method) were conducted using the Bruker APEX3 suite with implemented SADABS software. OLEX2 software containing ShelX package was used for structure solution and refinement. All structures were solved by intrinsic phasing or direct methods with programs ShelXT-2014 or ShelXS-2008, respectively, and were refined with program ShelXL-2014 using the least-squares method.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Crystal structures of all synthesized compounds were determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD). with either Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) or Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) radiation and Bruker D8 Quest fixed-chi diffractometer equipped with Photon II or Photon 100 detector, and the nitrogen-flow Oxford Cryosystem attachment. Unit-cell determination, data reduction and absorption correction (multiscan method) were conducted using the Bruker APEX3 suite with implemented SADABS software. OLEX2 software containing ShelX package was used for structure solution and refinement. All structures were solved by intrinsic phasing or direct methods with programs ShelXT-2014 or ShelXS-2008, respectively, and were refined with program ShelXL-2014 using the least-squares method.

elements.content: p-Phenylenediamine (0.11 g, 1.0 mmol) and 4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde (0.21 g, 2.0 mmol) were ground until a free-flowing yellow powder was obtained. Upon addition of ∼100 μL of MeOH, the resultant yellow paste was further ground until a free-flowing deep yellow powder was obtained as pure product (ca. 10 min); η = 1.35 μL mg–1. Compound 1 was also prepared by milling of p-phenylenediamine (0.86 g, 8.0 mmol) and 4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde (1.71 g, 16.0 mmol) with the addition of ∼100 μL of MeOH for 15 min in 98.0% yield; η = 1.86 μL mg–1. Alternately, compound 1 was also prepared by dropwise addition of 4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde (0.21 g, 2.0 mmol) to a solution of p-phenylenediamine (0.11 g, 1.0 mmol) in 3 mL of MeOH. Upon completion of reaction, as determined by TLC analysis, the solvent was removed in vacuo and pure product was isolated as a yellow solid by recrystallization using MeOH and subsequent heating at 100°C in 95.4% yield; η = 28.95 μL mg–1. The following spectroscopic data were collected on SDG sample: mp 182–186 °C; FTIR (ATR) cm–1 1624 (νCH=N); 1H NMR (270 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.44 (s, 4H), 7.85 (d, 4H, J = 5.94 Hz), 8.75 (d, 4H, J = 5.94 Hz), 8.74 (s, 2H); 13C NMR (67.5 MHz, CDCl3) δ 122.1, 122.4, 142.4, 149.1, 150.4, 158.9. Completion of the reaction was confirmed based on PXRD data. Five strongest peaks in the PXRD pattern calculated based on single-crystal data (PEXXEW) are at 14.27°, 19.85°, 23.15°, 24.12° and 28.74° 2θ angle. As shown in Figure S1, the experimental PXRD of the SDG sample shows five strongest peaks at 14.27°, 19.66°, 23.22°, 24.13° and 28.80°. The relative intensity and position of peaks confirmed that compound 1 was obtained in anhydrate form. Meanwhile, 2θ angles for five strongest peaks in PXRD patterns for for the ball milled sample, 19.67°, 21.15°, 21.74°, 23.11° and 26.9°, are consistent with those found in the PXRD pattern calculated based on single-crystal data for monohydrate of 1 (HIRLUQ).

elements.content: 1,5-Diaminonaphthalene (0.08 g, 0.5 mmol) and 4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde (0.11 g, 1.0 mmol) were ground until a free-flowing yellow powder was obtained. Upon addition of ∼100 μL of MeOH the resultant yellow paste was further ground (ca. 10 min) until a free-flowing deep yellow powder was obtained as pure product; η = 2.46 μL mg–1. Compound 2 was also prepared by milling of 1,5-diaminonaphthalene (1.26 g, 8.0 mmol) and 4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde (1.71 g, 16.0 mmol) with the addition of ∼100 μL of MeOH for 15 min in 98.6% yield; η = 1.27 μL mg–1. Alternately, compound 2 was prepared by dropwise addition of 4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde (0.11 g, 1.0 mmol) to a solution of 1,5-diaminonaphthalene (0.08 g, 0.5 mmol) in 8 mL of MeOH/CHCl3 (1:1 v/v) mixture. Upon completion of reaction, as determined by TLC analysis, the solvent was removed in vacuo and pure product recrystallized using MeOH/CHCl3 (1:1 v/v) as a yellow solid in 97.5% yield; η = 2.45 μL mg–1. The following spectroscopic data were collected on the SDG sample: mp 252–258 °C; FTIR (ATR) cm–1 1620 (νCH=N); 1H NMR (270 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.16 (d, 2H, J = 7.18 Hz), 7.53 (t, 2H, J = 7.78 Hz), 7.88 (d, 4H, J = 5.18 Hz), 8.28 (d, 2H, J = 8.67 Hz), 8.58 (s, 2H), 8.81 (d, 4H, J = 5.18 Hz); 13C NMR (67.5 MHz, CDCl3) δ 113.9, 122.1, 122.4, 126.3, 128.8, 142.5, 147.3, 150.5, 159.8. Five strongest peaks in the PXRD pattern calculated for the single-crystal structure of 2 are present at 2θ angle of 14.91°, 19.37°, 20.24°, 24.13° and 25.22°. This is in agreement with position of five strongest peaks present in experimental PXRD patterns of the SDG, as well as ball milled sample: 14.93°, 19.47°, 20.22°, 24.24° and 25.27°, Figure S5.

elements.content: 5-Aminoquinoline (0.14 g, 1.0 mmol) and 4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde (0.10 g, 1.0 mmol) were ground until a free-flowing yellow powder was obtained. Upon addition of ∼100 μL of MeOH, the resultant yellow paste was further ground (ca. 10 min) until a free-flowing deep yellow powder was obtained as pure product; η = 1.34 μL mg–1. Compound 3 was also prepared by milling of 5-aminoquinoline (1.15 g, 8.0 mmol) and 4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde (0.85 g, 8.0 mmol) with the addition of ∼100 μL of MeOH for 15 min in 98.5% yield; η = 0.74 μL mg–1. Alternately, compound 3 was also prepared by dropwise addition of 4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde (0.10 g, 1.0 mmol) to a solution of 5-aminoquinoline (0.14 g, 1.0 mmol) in 2.5 mL of MeCN. The contents were allowed to stir at rt for 10 min to ensure the completion of reaction after which the contents were concentrated in vacuo. Pure product was isolated as a yellow solid upon recrystallization using MeCN as solvent in 97.0% yield; η = 18.48 μL mg–1. TGA revealed a variable weight loss of 7–9% at ∼75 °C (Figure S12). The yellow solid was further heated at 75 °C for 2 h to isolate anhydrous product. The following spectroscopic data were collected on SDG sample: mp 91–94 °C; FTIR (ATR) cm–1 1602 (νCH=N); 1H NMR (270 MHz, DMSO-d 6) δ 7.45 (d, 1H, J = 7.76 Hz), 7.58 (dd, 1H, J = 8.53 Hz), 7.80 (t, 1H, J = 7.92 Hz), 7.95 (s, 1H), 7.98–8.01 (m, 2H), 8.73 (d, 1H, J = 7.76 Hz), 8.80–8.84 (m, 3H), 8.97 (d, 1H, J = 4.21 Hz); 13C NMR (67.5 MHz, DMSO-d 6) δ 113.8, 121.6, 122.5, 123.7, 127.5, 129.7, 132.0, 142.4, 147.4, 148.0, 150.6, 151.1, 160.7. Five strongest peaks in the PXRD pattern calculated for the single-crystal structure of 3 are present at 2θ angle of 8.54°, 16.58°, 24.47°, 25.92° and 26.92°. This is in agreement with position of five strongest peaks in experimental PXRD patterns of the SDG, as well as ball milled sample: 8.54°, 16.63°, 24.57°, 25.97° and 26.67°, Figure S9.

Synthesis of Compound sql-5-Ni-4i (C52H40N14NiO6)

A mixture of Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.01 g, 0.05 mmol) and N,N'-(1,4-phenylenebis(methan-1-yl-1-ylidene))bis(4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)aniline (5) (0.04 g, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 4 mL of DMF/MeOH (3:1 v/v). Yellow uneven single crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction were obtained; yield 67%.

For detailed synthetic procedures, characterization data and extended experimental description, see the Supporting Information (SI).

Results and Discussion

The library of linker ligands reported herein was prepared from three aromatic aldehydes and five primary amines, as shown in . The following aldehydes were used: 4-pyridinecarboxldehyde, terephthalaldehyde and 4-carboxybenzaldehyde (orange, ). The following amines were used: p-phenylenediamine, 1,5-diaminonaphthalene, 5-aminoquinoline, 4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)­aniline and 4-aminopyridine (gray and white, ). These substrates were selected since they offer functional groups suitable for use as linkers between transition metal cations. Imines 1–8 were prepared by grinding (manual or ball mill) an aromatic aldehyde with an amine. Small amounts (∼100 μL) of polar solvent were added to facilitate the reaction, i.e., solvent drop grinding (SDG) or liquid-assisted grinding (LAG) was conducted. The solvents were selected using solvent selection guidelines developed by industry. A list of preferred solvents commonly used in medicinal chemistry are water, acetone, ethanol, methanol, 2-propanol, 1-propanol, ethyl acetate, isopropyl acetate, methyl ethyl ketone, 1-butanol and t-butanol. Since it has been previously shown that Schiff bases can be synthesized in solid-state in the presence of small amounts of MeOH, first it was attempted to synthesize all compounds 1–8 by using methanol. Only when it failed, we have proceeded to alcohols of larger molecules, until final products were successfully obtained. As a result, MeOH was used to prepare 1–3 and 5–8 whereas iPrOH was used to synthesize 4. All compounds were obtained in quantitative yields. Given that 1–4 were prepared from a liquid aldehyde, 4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde, 1–4 were also prepared in quantitative yields by dropwise addition of 4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde to a solution of the corresponding amine.

elements.content: We determined that 1–8 are amenable to S3 and that they can be prepared in multigram quantities in >95% yield under ambient conditions and short reaction times (<15 min). Reactions affording 5–8 were complete within 5 min, but those affording 1–4 required ∼15 min, perhaps because 4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde is a liquid. Crystals of 1–8 were obtained by slow evaporation from pure solvents (MeOH, MeCN, EtOH, and acetone) or a solvent mixture (CHCl3/MeOH). For detailed information, see the SI. 1–8 were characterized by Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR), 1H and 13C Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopies and single crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD). A detailed description of syntheses, characterization, crystallographic and refinement parameters is provided in the SI. New crystal structures have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC 1588255, 1588257–1588266, 1831411).

elements.content: 1 is a symmetric diimine with pyridyl rings on either side of a benzene core, . Three crystal structures of 1 were investigated by us in the context of a study on hydrate formation: the anhydrate (PEXXEW), a monohydrate (HIRLUQ) and a tetrahydrate (OXUHIA02). In each case, the molecule adopts a nonplanar conformation (Table S1). The anhydrous form exhibits two independent molecules and dihedral angles between the pyridyl and phenyl rings of 53.29° and 58.10° (Table S1). These conformational differences may be due to intermolecular interactions. The tetrahydrate of 1 with half a molecule of 1 and two water molecules comprising the asymmetric unit. The dihedral angles between the pyridyl and phenyl rings (52.49°) are comparable to those observed in the anhydrous form, Table S1. The monohydrate (HIRLUQ) has one molecule of 1 in a general position. The dihedral angles between pyridyl and phenyl rings are 24.96°and 43.79°, and between the two pyridyl rings are 68.60° and 70.46° (Table S1). We examined the torsion angles about the C2–C3 bond (, 2.38(19)–9.98(6)°) while torsion angles about the N4–C5 bond range from 28.72(2)–47.87(5)° (Table S1). The conformations observed in the three crystal structures of 1 indicate torsional flexibility. A detailed description of crystal packing is provided in SI.

Description of Molecular Structures

Bis(pyridin-4-ylmethylene)benzene-1,4-diamine (1)

 1 is a symmetric diimine with pyridyl rings on either side of a benzene core, . Three crystal structures of 1 were investigated by us in the context of a study on hydrate formation: the anhydrate (PEXXEW), a monohydrate (HIRLUQ) and a tetrahydrate (OXUHIA02). In each case, the molecule adopts a nonplanar conformation (Table S1). The anhydrous form exhibits two independent molecules and dihedral angles between the pyridyl and phenyl rings of 53.29° and 58.10° (Table S1). These conformational differences may be due to intermolecular interactions. The tetrahydrate of 1 with half a molecule of 1 and two water molecules comprising the asymmetric unit. The dihedral angles between the pyridyl and phenyl rings (52.49°) are comparable to those observed in the anhydrous form, Table S1. The monohydrate (HIRLUQ) has one molecule of 1 in a general position. The dihedral angles between pyridyl and phenyl rings are 24.96°and 43.79°, and between the two pyridyl rings are 68.60° and 70.46° (Table S1). We examined the torsion angles about the C2-C3 bond (, 2.38(19)-9.98(6)°) while torsion angles about the N4-C5 bond range from 28.72(2)-47.87(5)° (Table S1). The conformations observed in the three crystal structures of 1 indicate torsional flexibility. A detailed description of crystal packing is provided in SI.

elements.content: 2 is a symmetric diimine containing 1,5-disubstituted pyridyl rings on both sides of a naphthalene core, . As a result, the molecule has a Z-shaped geometry. The crystal structure of 2 has been previously reported (XAPTEO). We isolated a new polymorph of 2 by slow evaporation of a solution of 2 in MeOH/CHCl3. SCXRD data reveals that the second polymorph crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n with half a molecule of 2 comprising the asymmetric unit. In XAPTEO the asymmetric unit contains two crystallographically independent half molecules of 2. In both crystal structures, the molecule is nonplanar and flexible with dihedral angles between the pyridyl and naphthyl rings of 62.52° (new polymorph) and 53.85° and 57.52° (XAPTEO), Table S1. The torsion angles about the C2–C3 and N4–C5 bonds in the new polymorph are 13.40(1)° and 132.18(1)°, respectively (), vs 1.14(1)° and 129.05(1)°, for one crystallographically independent molecule in XAPTEO and 6.78(1)° and 133.32(1)° for the other molecule (Table S1).

elements.content: 7 is a positional isomer of 1 with respect to the imine substitution, . Its synthesis from solution has been previously reported; however, there are no reported crystal structures. We isolated four crystal forms of 7: two polymorphs (7α and 7β), a cocrystal with 4-aminopyridine (AMP) (7·AMP) and a hydrate (7·4H2O). 7α crystallized in P1̅ with two crystallographically independent halves of 7 comprising the asymmetric unit. 7β crystallized in the monoclinic space group P21/c with half a molecule of 7 comprising the asymmetric unit. 7·AMP crystallized in the monoclinic space group P21/c with 1.5 molecules of 7 and one molecule of 4-aminopyridine comprising the asymmetric unit. 7•4H2O crystallized in P21/c with half a molecule of 7 and two H2O molecules comprising the asymmetric unit. In each case, 7 adopts a nonplanar conformation with conformational flexibility: dihedral angles between the pyridyl and phenyl rings are 41.48–63.65°; torsion angles about the C2–C3 and N4–C5 bonds () are 3.13(1)–8.94(1)° and 40.23(1)–56.20(1)°, respectively (see Table S1).

elements.content: Overall, five out of eight Schiff bases reported herein afforded anhydrous forms (2, 4, 5, 7α, 7β, 8). Additionally, three hydrates (1, 3 and 7) and one heterosolvate (6) were obtained. In the case of 1 and 7, isolated site mono- and tetrahydrates were isolated, respectively, while the hydrate of 3 is interesting in that there are two independent regions occupied by water molecules. One can be characterized as isolated site in which H2O molecules are H-bonded to the nitrogen atom of the quinoline moiety. The other water molecule lies in a 1D channel filled with disordered water molecules. In the case of 6, there is one solvent molecule per 0.5 molecules of 6. However, the site occupied by solvent molecules is disordered between methanol and water in a 3:7 ratio. The molecules that lack a center of inversion (3, 4, 8) exhibit Z′ = 1 in two cases (4 and 8) whereas 3, the smallest molecule studied herein, formed a hydrate with Z′ = 2. 7α exhibits quite different conformations with a difference of the dihedral angle between pyridine and benzene rings of about 17°. In the remaining structures (1, PEXXEW; 2, XAPTEO and 5), the difference between dihedral angles ranges from 1.18° to 4.81°. 2 and 7 exhibit polymorphs with Z′ = 0.5 (2, 7β). Overall, 1–8 adopt nonplanar conformations in their crystal structures. The dihedral angles between rings vary from 3.32 to 79.75° but mainly lie between 40 and 60° (16 cases). 1–8 exhibit similarities in the geometry of the imine fragment. The CN bond lengths range from 1.250(1) to 1.278(1) Å, in good agreement with the expected values. A detailed summary of the bond distances, and dihedral and torsion angles for 1–8 is presented in Table S1. All imine molecules exist as the trans isomer. This is due to the polarized character of the imine group, which inhibits isolation of cis isomers for most Schiff bases. Indeed, a study of dipole moments and absorption spectra of benzylideneaniline derivatives concluded that these compounds exist as trans isomers. Further, when the CN fragment of an imine moiety is conjugated, as is the case for 1–8, the cis isomer might not exist at all. A CSD survey (ConQuest 1.20, CSD v5.39 November 2017, 3D coordinates determined, nondisordered, no errors, single crystal structures) revealed that in neutral, acyclic secondary aldimine moieties the trans configuration (torsion angle > 170°) strongly prevails over the cis configuration (torsion angle < 10°). Out of 5771 torsion angles in 4164 structures, 5720 were found to be trans (99.12%) and only four were observed to be cis (0.07%) secondary aldimine moieties.

elements.content: 5 was used to prepare a coordination network of formula [Ni­(N,N′-(1,4-phenylenebis­(methan-1-yl-1-ylidene))­bis­(4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)­aniline)2(NO3)2] n (Sql-5-Ni-4i) (). Sql-5-Ni-4i was synthesized via solvothermal reaction of 5 and Ni­(NO3)2 in a mixture of DMF/MeOH (). Full synthetic details are provided in the SI. The crystal structure of Sql-5-Ni-4i was determined by SCXRD from data collected at 100 K. Sql-5-Ni-4i crystallizes in P21/c with one Ni2+ cation, two nitrate anions and two molecules of 5 comprising the asymmetric unit. Each Ni2+ cation adopts octahedral coordination geometry with nitrogen atoms from four bis imidazolyl linker ligands forming the equatorial plane. The Ni–N bond lengths range from 2.060(1) to 2.082(1) Å, which is comparable to previously reported values. The octahedral coordination geometry is completed with two axial nitrate anions. The Ni–O bond lengths, 2.168(1) and 2.234(1) Å, are in good agreement with values in similar coordination polymers. The four organic linker ligands bridge to adjacent Ni2+ cations, resulting an sql topology structure (a) with 25.3 Å × 25.7 Å windows (a). The size of these square windows facilitates interpenetration of the sql networks. In Sql-5-Ni-4i, 2D networks are parallel interpenetrated with respect to each other as illustrated in b,c resulting in 4-fold 2D → 2D interpenetration (d). Additionally, the conformational flexibility of 5 enables a plethora of C–H···O and C–H···N hydrogen bonds between networks. The conformation of 5 in Sql-5-Ni-4i differs from that adopted by 5, with a dihedral angle between the two imidazolyl groups of 51.5° and 88.1°. Dihedral and torsion angles and bond distances observed in the crystal structure of Sql-5-Ni-4i are listed in Table S2 (SI).

elements.content: The phenomenon of interpenetration is being increasingly encountered as the number of coordination polymers has grown and linker ligands have increased in length. TOPOS reveals that there are ca. 10 000 sql coordination networks already reported, of which 789 (∼8%) are interpenetrated 2D square lattices (2D-sql-i), 345 of which (44%) exhibit parallel interpenetration. 336 structures (43%) exhibit 2D → 3D parallel and inclined interpenetration. Whereas the type of interpenetration observed in Sql-5-Ni-4i is commonly observed, it is unusual with respect to the degree of interpenetration (). The structure of Sql-5-Ni-4i is to our knowledge only the fourth example of 2D → 2D 4-fold parallel interpenetration.

Whereas the type of interpenetration observed in Sql-5-Ni-4i is commonly observed, it is unusual with respect to the degree of interpenetration (). The structure of Sql-5-Ni-4i is to our knowledge only the fourth example of 2D → 2D 4-fold parallel interpenetration.

elements.content: We report high yield, low-waste synthesis of eight Schiff bases, 1–8 with use of mechanochemistry. 3–6 and 8 are new chemical entities and all eight compounds were prepared in multigram scale in quantitative yields (>95%). 1–4 were also synthesized quantitatively in solution. These results demonstrate that mechanochemistry can be utilized for synthesis of a library of Schiff bases with potential utility as linker ligands. The prototypal linker ligand, bipy, is the most commonly used linker ligand in the CSD MOF subset. The results obtained using bipy suggest that 1–8 are likely to be suitable for use in new coordination networks with sql, dia and pcu topologies. 5 was indeed used for the synthesis of Sql-5-Ni-4i, a coordination network with 4-fold 2D → 2D parallel interpenetration. That linker ligands 1–8 were prepared mechanochemically could be important if such ligands are ultimately used for industrial scale applications. In particular, they are likely to be amenable to synthesis using a twin-screw extruder, a continuous process which enables scale-up. Given that the James group has demonstrated that MOFs can be prepared using single -and twin screw extruders, the possibility of a single continuous process for ligand and MOF synthesis becomes apparent.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We report high yield, low-waste synthesis of eight Schiff bases, 1-8 with use of mechanochemistry. 3-6 and 8 are new chemical entities and all eight compounds were prepared in multigram scale in quantitative yields (>95%). 1-4 were also synthesized quantitatively in solution. These results demonstrate that mechanochemistry can be utilized for synthesis of a library of Schiff bases with potential utility as linker ligands. The prototypal linker ligand, bipy, is the most commonly used linker ligand in the CSD MOF subset. The results obtained using bipy suggest that 1-8 are likely to be suitable for use in new coordination networks with sql, dia and pcu topologies. 5 was indeed used for the synthesis of Sql-5-Ni-4i, a coordination network with 4-fold 2D → 2D parallel interpenetration. That linker ligands 1-8 were prepared mechanochemically could be important if such ligands are ultimately used for industrial scale applications. In particular, they are likely to be amenable to synthesis using a twin-screw extruder, a continuous process which enables scale-up. Given that the James group has demonstrated that MOFs can be prepared using single -and twin screw extruders, the possibility of a single continuous process for ligand and MOF synthesis becomes apparent.

elements.content: To conclude, the synthetic approach reported herein paves the way for the design and synthesis of large libraries of closely related organic linker ligands that will enable better understanding of structure–property relationships in porous coordination networks. Future work will focus upon further expanding the library of Schiff base linker ligands and using them to generate novel coordination networks.

p-Phenylenediamine (0.11 g, 1.0 mmol) and 4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde (0.21 g, 2.0 mmol) were ground until a free-flowing yellow powder was obtained. Upon addition of ∼100 μL of MeOH, the resultant yellow paste was further ground until a free-flowing deep yellow powder was obtained as pure product (ca. 10 min); η = 1.35 μL mg–1. Compound 1 was also prepared by milling of p-phenylenediamine (0.86 g, 8.0 mmol) and 4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde (1.71 g, 16.0 mmol) with the addition of ∼100 μL of MeOH for 15 min in 98.0% yield; η = 1.86 μL mg–1. Alternately, compound 1 was also prepared by dropwise addition of 4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde (0.21 g, 2.0 mmol) to a solution of p-phenylenediamine (0.11 g, 1.0 mmol) in 3 mL of MeOH. Upon completion of reaction, as determined by TLC analysis, the solvent was removed in vacuo and pure product was isolated as a yellow solid by recrystallization using MeOH and subsequent heating at 100°C in 95.4% yield; η = 28.95 μL mg–1. The following spectroscopic data were collected on SDG sample: mp 182–186 °C; FTIR (ATR) cm–1 1624 (νCH=N); 1H NMR (270 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.44 (s, 4H), 7.85 (d, 4H, J = 5.94 Hz), 8.75 (d, 4H, J = 5.94 Hz), 8.74 (s, 2H); 13C NMR (67.5 MHz, CDCl3) δ 122.1, 122.4, 142.4, 149.1, 150.4, 158.9. Completion of the reaction was confirmed based on PXRD data. Five strongest peaks in the PXRD pattern calculated based on single-crystal data (PEXXEW) are at 14.27°, 19.85°, 23.15°, 24.12° and 28.74° 2θ angle. As shown in Figure S1, the experimental PXRD of the SDG sample shows five strongest peaks at 14.27°, 19.66°, 23.22°, 24.13° and 28.80°. The relative intensity and position of peaks confirmed that compound 1 was obtained in anhydrate form. Meanwhile, 2θ angles for five strongest peaks in PXRD patterns for for the ball milled sample, 19.67°, 21.15°, 21.74°, 23.11° and 26.9°, are consistent with those found in the PXRD pattern calculated based on single-crystal data for monohydrate of 1 (HIRLUQ).

<italic>N</italic>,<italic>N</italic>′-Bis­(4-pyridylmethylene)­naphthalene-1,5-diamine (<bold>2</bold>)

1,5-Diaminonaphthalene (0.08 g, 0.5 mmol) and 4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde (0.11 g, 1.0 mmol) were ground until a free-flowing yellow powder was obtained. Upon addition of ∼100 μL of MeOH the resultant yellow paste was further ground (ca. 10 min) until a free-flowing deep yellow powder was obtained as pure product; η = 2.46 μL mg–1. Compound 2 was also prepared by milling of 1,5-diaminonaphthalene (1.26 g, 8.0 mmol) and 4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde (1.71 g, 16.0 mmol) with the addition of ∼100 μL of MeOH for 15 min in 98.6% yield; η = 1.27 μL mg–1. Alternately, compound 2 was prepared by dropwise addition of 4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde (0.11 g, 1.0 mmol) to a solution of 1,5-diaminonaphthalene (0.08 g, 0.5 mmol) in 8 mL of MeOH/CHCl3 (1:1 v/v) mixture. Upon completion of reaction, as determined by TLC analysis, the solvent was removed in vacuo and pure product recrystallized using MeOH/CHCl3 (1:1 v/v) as a yellow solid in 97.5% yield; η = 2.45 μL mg–1. The following spectroscopic data were collected on the SDG sample: mp 252–258 °C; FTIR (ATR) cm–1 1620 (νCH=N); 1H NMR (270 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.16 (d, 2H, J = 7.18 Hz), 7.53 (t, 2H, J = 7.78 Hz), 7.88 (d, 4H, J = 5.18 Hz), 8.28 (d, 2H, J = 8.67 Hz), 8.58 (s, 2H), 8.81 (d, 4H, J = 5.18 Hz); 13C NMR (67.5 MHz, CDCl3) δ 113.9, 122.1, 122.4, 126.3, 128.8, 142.5, 147.3, 150.5, 159.8. Five strongest peaks in the PXRD pattern calculated for the single-crystal structure of 2 are present at 2θ angle of 14.91°, 19.37°, 20.24°, 24.13° and 25.22°. This is in agreement with position of five strongest peaks present in experimental PXRD patterns of the SDG, as well as ball milled sample: 14.93°, 19.47°, 20.22°, 24.24° and 25.27°, Figure S5.

<italic>N</italic>-(Pyridin-4-ylmethylene)­quinolin-5-amine (<bold>3</bold>)

5-Aminoquinoline (0.14 g, 1.0 mmol) and 4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde (0.10 g, 1.0 mmol) were ground until a free-flowing yellow powder was obtained. Upon addition of ∼100 μL of MeOH, the resultant yellow paste was further ground (ca. 10 min) until a free-flowing deep yellow powder was obtained as pure product; η = 1.34 μL mg–1. Compound 3 was also prepared by milling of 5-aminoquinoline (1.15 g, 8.0 mmol) and 4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde (0.85 g, 8.0 mmol) with the addition of ∼100 μL of MeOH for 15 min in 98.5% yield; η = 0.74 μL mg–1. Alternately, compound 3 was also prepared by dropwise addition of 4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde (0.10 g, 1.0 mmol) to a solution of 5-aminoquinoline (0.14 g, 1.0 mmol) in 2.5 mL of MeCN. The contents were allowed to stir at rt for 10 min to ensure the completion of reaction after which the contents were concentrated in vacuo. Pure product was isolated as a yellow solid upon recrystallization using MeCN as solvent in 97.0% yield; η = 18.48 μL mg–1. TGA revealed a variable weight loss of 7–9% at ∼75 °C (Figure S12). The yellow solid was further heated at 75 °C for 2 h to isolate anhydrous product. The following spectroscopic data were collected on SDG sample: mp 91–94 °C; FTIR (ATR) cm–1 1602 (νCH=N); 1H NMR (270 MHz, DMSO-d 6) δ 7.45 (d, 1H, J = 7.76 Hz), 7.58 (dd, 1H, J = 8.53 Hz), 7.80 (t, 1H, J = 7.92 Hz), 7.95 (s, 1H), 7.98–8.01 (m, 2H), 8.73 (d, 1H, J = 7.76 Hz), 8.80–8.84 (m, 3H), 8.97 (d, 1H, J = 4.21 Hz); 13C NMR (67.5 MHz, DMSO-d 6) δ 113.8, 121.6, 122.5, 123.7, 127.5, 129.7, 132.0, 142.4, 147.4, 148.0, 150.6, 151.1, 160.7. Five strongest peaks in the PXRD pattern calculated for the single-crystal structure of 3 are present at 2θ angle of 8.54°, 16.58°, 24.47°, 25.92° and 26.92°. This is in agreement with position of five strongest peaks in experimental PXRD patterns of the SDG, as well as ball milled sample: 8.54°, 16.63°, 24.57°, 25.97° and 26.67°, Figure S9.

<italic>N</italic>,<italic>N</italic>′-(1,4-Phenylenebis­(methan-1-yl-1-ylidene))­bis­(4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)­aniline) (<bold>5</bold>)

Terephthalaldehyde (0.13 g, 1.0 mmol) and 4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)­aniline (0.31 g, 2.0 mmol) were ground until a free-flowing powder was obtained. Upon addition of ∼100 μL of MeOH the resultant paste was further ground (ca. 10 min) until a free-flowing deep yellow powder was obtained as pure product; η = 0.23 μL mg–1. TGA revealed a weight loss of 1.6% at 200 °C (Figure S20). Hence, this deep yellow solid was heated at 200 °C for 3 h to isolate pure product as a dark brown solid. Compound 5 was also prepared by milling of terephthalaldehyde (0.67 g, 5.0 mmol) and 4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)­aniline (1.59 g, 10.0 mmol) with the addition of ∼100 μL of MeOH for 5 min; η = 0.04 μL mg–1. The final product was also obtained by dry milling the starting materials for 20 min. Yield 98.0%. The following spectroscopic data were collected on the heated sample: mp >300 °C; FTIR (ATR) cm–1 1623 (νCH=N). 1H NMR (270 MHz, DMSO-d 6) δ 7.12 (s, 2H), 7.49 (d, 4H, J = 8.79 Hz), 7.74 (d, 4H, J = 8.79 Hz), 7.80 (s, 2H), 8.11 (s, 4H), 8.31 (s, 2H), 8.80 (s, 2H); 13C NMR (67.5 MHz, DMSO-d 6) δ 118.0, 121.1, 122.6, 129.1, 129.9, 135.0, 135.4, 138.4, 149.4, 160.3. Five strongest peaks in the PXRD pattern calculated for the single-crystal structure of 5 are present at 2θ angle of 13.05°, 20.70°, 23.52°, 24.81° and 29.16°. This is in agreement with position of five strongest peaks present in experimental PXRD patterns of SDG, as well as ball milled sample: 13.05°, 20.80°, 23.62°, 24.95° and 29.25° Figure S17.

<italic>N</italic>,<italic>N</italic>′-(1,4-Phenylenebis­(methan-1-yl-1-ylidene))­diquinolin-5-amine (<bold>6</bold>)

Terephthalaldehyde (0.13 g, 1.0 mmol) and 5-aminoquinoline (0.23 g, 2.0 mmol) were ground until a free-flowing powder was obtained. Upon addition of ∼100 μL of MeOH the resultant paste was further ground (ca. 10 min) until a free-flowing deep yellow powder was obtained as pure product; η = 0.28 μL mg–1. TGA revealed a variable weight loss of 8–15% at 150 °C (Figure S24). To isolate the pure anhydrous product, the yellow solid was heated at 150 °C for 2 h. Compound 6 was also prepared by milling of terephthalaldehyde (0.67 g, 5.0 mmol) and 5-aminoquinoline (1.44 g, 10.0 mmol) with the addition of ∼100 μL of MeOH for 5 min. Deep yellow solid was obtained as pure product in 98.5% yield; η = 0.05 μL mg–1. The following spectroscopic data were collected on the heated sample: mp 227–231 °C; FTIR (ATR) cm–1 1616 (νCH=N); 1H NMR (270 MHz, DMSO-d 6,) δ 7.45 (d, 2H, J = 7.18 Hz), 7.60 (dd, 2H, J = 8.42 Hz, J = 4.20 Hz), 7.81 (t, 2H, J = 7.91 Hz), 7.95 (d, 2H, J = 8.40 Hz), 7.95 (d, 2H, J = 8.40 Hz), 8.27 (s, 4H), 8.67 (d, 2H, J = 9.45 Hz), 8.90 (s, 2H), 8.97 (dd, 2H, J = 4.10 Hz, J = 1.45 Hz); 13C NMR (67.5 MHz, DMSO-d 6) δ 113.5, 121.3, 123.8, 127.0, 129.4, 129.7, 131.8, 138.6, 147.9, 148.0, 151.0, 161.3. Five strongest peaks in the PXRD pattern calculated for the single-crystal structure of 6 are present at 2θ angle of 6.98°, 7.62°, 16.27°, 24.20° and 26.99°. This is in agreement with position of five strongest peaks present in experimental PXRD patterns of SDG: 6.90°, 7.63°, 16.03°, 24.25° and 26.96° as well as the ball milled sample: 6.90°, 7.59°, 16.07°, 24.03° and 26.61°, Figure S21. A slight shift in the position of the five strongest peaks is due to the difference in the temperature at which single-crystal and powder X-ray diffraction data were collected. However, the relative intensity, and similar position of those peaks confirmed obtainment of the product.

<italic>N</italic>,<italic>N</italic>′-(1,4-Phenylenebis­(methan-1-yl-1-ylidene))­dipyridine-4-amine (<bold>7</bold>)

Terephthalaldehyde (0.13 g, 1.0 mmol) and 4-aminopyridine (AMP) (0.19 g, 2.0 mmol) were ground until a free-flowing powder was obtained. Upon addition of ∼100 μL MeOH, the resultant paste was further ground until a free-flowing white powder was obtained (ca. 10 min); η = 0.31 μL mg–1. PXRD revealed presence of unreacted starting materials. Hence, the powder was heated at 120 °C for 1 h for completion of reaction. As a result, yellow needle-shaped crystals were obtained. To isolate pure product, the heated sample was recrystallized from acetone, acetonitrile and ethanol; Yield 95.2%. The following spectroscopic data were collected on the recrystallized sample: mp 243–252 °C; FTIR (ATR) cm–1 1604 (νCH=N); 1H NMR (270 MHz, DMSO-d 6) δ 7.24 (d, 4H, J = 5.25 Hz), 8.12 (s, 4H), 8.57 (d, 4H, J = 5.25 Hz), 8.71 (s, 2H); 13C NMR (67.5 MHz, DMSO-d 6) δ 115.9, 129.6, 138.2, 150.7, 163.4. Five strongest peaks in the PXRD pattern calculated for the single-crystal structure of 7·4H2O are present at 2θ angle of 7.45°, 12.54°, 18.63°, 24.95° and 27.04°. This is in agreement with position of five strongest peaks present in experimental PXRD patterns of as-synthesized sample: 7.35°, 12.40°, 18.47°, 24.51° and 26.58°, Figure S26. A slight shift in the position of the five strongest peaks is due to the difference in the temperature at which single-crystal and powder X-ray diffraction data were collected. However, the relative intensity and similar position of those peaks confirmed obtainment of the product. Also five strongest peaks in the PXRD pattern calculated for the single-crystal structure of anhydrate polymorph 7α are present at 2θ angle of 20.26°, 21.80°, 22.54°, 24.42° and 28.56°. This is in agreement with position of five strongest peaks present in experimental PXRD patterns of compound 7 heated at 120°C: 20.10°, 21.55°, 22.24°, 24.07° and 28.17°, Figure S26. A slight shift in the position of these peaks is due to the difference in the temperature at which single-crystal and powder X-ray diffraction data were collected. However, the relative intensity, and similar position of those peaks confirmed obtainment of the product.

4-((4-(1H-Imidazol-1-yl)­phenylimino)­methyl)­benzoic acid (<bold>8</bold>)

4-Carboxybenzaldehyde (0.15 g, 1.0 mmol) and 4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)­aniline (0.16 g, 1.0 mmol) were ground until a free-flowing powder was obtained. Upon addition of ∼100 μL of MeOH, the resultant paste was further ground (ca. 10 min) until a free-flowing pale yellow colored powder was obtained (ca. 10 min); η = 0.32 μL mg–1. TGA revealed a weight loss of 8.9% at 100 °C (Figure S33). Hence, this pale yellow solid was heated at 100 °C for 5 h to obtain product as yellow solid. Pure product was isolated by recrystallization from CHCl3/MeOH (1:1 v/v) mixture. Compound 8 was also prepared by milling of 4-carboxybenzaldehyde (0.75 g, 5.0 mmol) and 4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)­aniline (0.79 g, 5.0 mmol) with the addition of ∼100 μL of MeOH for 5 min in 97.0% yield; η = 0.06 μL mg–1. The following spectroscopic data were collected on the heated sample: mp 286–296 °C; FTIR (ATR) cm–1 1627 (νCH=N); 1H NMR (270 MHz, DMSO-d 6) δ 8.80 (s, 1H), 8.31 (s, 1H), 8.07 (s, 4H), 7.80 (s, 1H), 7.74 (d, 2H, J = 8.65 Hz), 7.48 (d, 2H, J = 8.65 Hz), 7.12 (s, 1H). 13C NMR (67.5 MHz, DMSO-d 6) δ 114.1, 121.1, 122.6, 128.8, 129.5, 130.0, 133.2, 135.6, 135.8, 139.5, 149.3, 160.3, 166.9. Five strongest peaks in the PXRD pattern calculated for the single-crystal structure of 8 are present at 2θ angle of 12.94°, 15.09°, 17.33°, 23.83° and 25.52°. This is in agreement with position of five strongest peaks present in experimental PXRD patterns of SDG, as well as the ball milled sample: 12.88°, 15.09°, 17.43°, 23.87° and 25.57°, Figure S30.

Synthesis of Compound sql-5-Ni-4i (C<sub>52</sub>H<sub>40</sub>N<sub>14</sub>NiO<sub>6</sub>)

A mixture of Ni­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.01 g, 0.05 mmol) and N,N′-(1,4-phenylenebis­(methan-1-yl-1-ylidene))­bis­(4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)­aniline (5) (0.04 g, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 4 mL of DMF/MeOH (3:1 v/v). The vial was sealed and heated at 120 °C for 2 days. The reaction system was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C per hour. Yellow uneven single crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction were obtained; yield 67%.

Five strongest peaks in the PXRD pattern calculated for the single-crystal structure of 5 are present at 2θ angle of 13.05°, 20.70°, 23.52°, 24.81° and 29.16°. This is in agreement with position of five strongest peaks present in experimental PXRD patterns of SDG, as well as ball milled sample: 13.05°, 20.80°, 23.62°, 24.95° and 29.25° Figure S17.

 N,N'-(1,4-Phenylenebis(methan-1-yl-1-ylidene))diquinolin-5-amine (6)

Terephthalaldehyde (0.13 g, 1.0 mmol) and 5-aminoquinoline (0.23 g, 2.0 mmol) were ground until a free-flowing powder was obtained. Upon addition of ~100 μL of MeOH the resultant paste was further ground (ca. 10 min) until a free-flowing deep yellow powder was obtained as pure product; η = 0.28 μL mg-1. TGA revealed a variable weight loss of 8-15% at 150 °C (Figure S24). To isolate the pure anhydrous product, the yellow solid was heated at 150 °C for 2 h. Compound 6 was also prepared by milling of terephthalaldehyde (0.67 g, 5.0 mmol) and 5-aminoquinoline (1.44 g, 10.0 mmol) with the addition of  ~100 μL of MeOH for 5 min. Deep yellow solid was obtained as pure product in 98.5% yield; η = 0.05 μL mg-1. The following spectroscopic data were collected on the heated sample: mp 227-231 °C; FTIR (ATR) cm-1 1616 (νCH=N); 1H NMR (270 MHz, DMSO-d 6,) δ 7.45 (d, 2H, J = 7.18 Hz), 7.60 (dd, 2H, J = 8.42 Hz, J = 4.20 Hz), 7.81 (t, 2H, J = 7.91 Hz), 7.95 (d, 2H, J = 8.40 Hz), 7.95 (d, 2H, J = 8.40 Hz), 8.27 (s, 4H), 8.67 (d, 2H, J = 9.45 Hz), 8.90 (s, 2H), 8.97 (dd, 2H, J = 4.10 Hz, J = 1.45 Hz); 13C NMR (67.5 MHz, DMSO-d 6) δ 113.5, 121.3, 123.8, 127.0, 129.4, 129.7, 131.8, 138.6, 147.9, 148.0, 151.0, 161.3. Five strongest peaks in the PXRD pattern calculated for the single-crystal structure of 6 are present at 2θ angle of 6.98°, 7.62°, 16.27°, 24.20° and 26.99°. This is in agreement with position of five strongest peaks present in experimental PXRD patterns of SDG: 6.90°, 7.63°, 16.03°, 24.25° and 26.96° as well as the ball milled sample: 6.90°, 7.59°, 16.07°, 24.03° and 26.61°, Figure S21. A slight shift in the position of the five strongest peaks is due to the difference in the temperature at which single-crystal and powder X-ray diffraction data were collected. However, the relative intensity, and similar position of those peaks confirmed obtainment of the product.

 N,N'-(1,4-Phenylenebis(methan-1-yl-1-ylidene))dipyridine-4-amine (7)

Terephthalaldehyde (0.13 g, 1.0 mmol) and 4-aminopyridine (AMP) (0.19 g, 2.0 mmol) were ground until a free-flowing powder was obtained. Upon addition of ~100 μL MeOH, the resultant paste was further ground until a free-flowing white powder was obtained (ca. 10 min); η = 0.31 μL mg-1. PXRD revealed presence of unreacted starting materials. Hence, the powder was heated at 120 °C for 1 h for completion of reaction. As a result, yellow needle-shaped crystals were obtained. To isolate pure product, the heated sample was recrystallized from acetone, acetonitrile and ethanol; Yield 95.2%. The following spectroscopic data were collected on the recrystallized sample: mp 243-252 °C; FTIR (ATR) cm-1 1604 (νCH=N); 1H NMR (270 MHz, DMSO-d 6) δ 7.24 (d, 4H, J = 5.25 Hz), 8.12 (s, 4H), 8.57 (d, 4H, J = 5.25 Hz), 8.71 (s, 2H); 13C NMR (67.5 MHz, DMSO-d 6) δ 115.9, 129.6, 138.2, 150.7, 163.4. Five strongest peaks in the PXRD pattern calculated for the single-crystal structure of 7⋅4H2O are present at 2θ angle of 7.45°, 12.54°, 18.63°, 24.95° and 27.04°. This is in agreement with position of five strongest peaks present in experimental PXRD patterns of as-synthesized sample: 7.35°, 12.40°, 18.47°, 24.51° and 26.58°, Figure S26. A slight shift in the position of the five strongest peaks is due to the difference in the temperature at which single-crystal and powder X-ray diffraction data were collected. However, the relative intensity and similar position of those peaks confirmed obtainment of the product. Also five strongest peaks in the PXRD pattern calculated for the single-crystal structure of anhydrate polymorph 7α are present at 2θ angle of 20.26°, 21.80°, 22.54°, 24.42° and 28.56°. This is in agreement with position of five strongest peaks present in experimental PXRD patterns of compound 7 heated at 120°C: 20.10°, 21.55°, 22.24°, 24.07° and 28.17°, Figure S26. A slight shift in the position of these peaks is due to the difference in the temperature at which single-crystal and powder X-ray diffraction data were collected. However, the relative intensity, and similar position of those peaks confirmed obtainment of the product.

4-((4-(1H-Imidazol-1-yl)phenylimino)methyl)benzoic acid (8)

4-Carboxybenzaldehyde (0.15 g, 1.0 mmol) and 4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)aniline (0.16 g, 1.0 mmol) were ground until a free-flowing powder was obtained. Upon addition of ~100 μL of MeOH, the resultant paste was further ground (ca. 10 min) until a free-flowing pale yellow colored powder was obtained (ca. 10 min); η = 0.32 μL mg-1. TGA revealed a weight loss of 8.9% at 100 °C (Figure S33). Hence, this pale yellow solid was heated at 100 °C for 5 h to obtain product as yellow solid. Pure product was isolated by recrystallization from CHCl3/MeOH (1:1 v/v) mixture. Compound 8 was also prepared by milling of 4-carboxybenzaldehyde (0.75 g, 5.0 mmol) and 4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)aniline (0.79 g, 5.0 mmol) with the addition of  ~100 μL of MeOH for 5 min in 97.0% yield; η = 0.06 μL mg-1. The following spectroscopic data were collected on the heated sample: mp 286-296 °C; FTIR (ATR) cm-1 1627 (νCH=N); 1H NMR (270 MHz, DMSO-d 6) δ 8.80 (s, 1H), 8.31 (s, 1H), 8.07 (s, 4H), 7.80 (s, 1H), 7.74 (d, 2H, J = 8.65 Hz), 7.48 (d, 2H, J = 8.65 Hz), 7.12 (s, 1H). 13C NMR (67.5 MHz, DMSO-d 6) δ 114.1, 121.1, 122.6, 128.8, 129.5, 130.0, 133.2, 135.6, 135.8, 139.5, 149.3, 160.3, 166.9. Five strongest peaks in the PXRD pattern calculated for the single-crystal structure of 8 are present at 2θ angle of 12.94°, 15.09°, 17.33°, 23.83° and 25.52°. This is in agreement with position of five strongest peaks present in experimental PXRD patterns of SDG, as well as the ball milled sample: 12.88°, 15.09°, 17.43°, 23.87° and 25.57°, Figure S30.

Synthesis of Compound sql-5-Ni-4i (C52H40N14NiO6)

A mixture of Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.01 g, 0.05 mmol) and N,N'-(1,4-phenylenebis(methan-1-yl-1-ylidene))bis(4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)aniline (5) (0.04 g, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 4 mL of DMF/MeOH (3:1 v/v). The vial was sealed and heated at 120 °C for 2 days. The reaction system was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C per hour. Yellow uneven single crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction were obtained; yield 67%.
